user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_rmfs:
```c
int32 OS_rmfs(const char *devname)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(devname);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, devname, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * NOTE: It is likely that if the file system is mounted,
         * this call to stop the volume will fail.
         *
         * It would be prudent to first check the flags to ensure that
         * the filesystem is unmounted first, but this would break
         * compatibility with the existing unit tests.
         */
        return_code = OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl(&token);

        /* Free the entry in the master table  */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_rmfs:
#define OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(str) OS_CHECK_STRING(str,OS_MAX_PATH_LEN,OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(lock_mode, idtype, OS_ObjectNameMatch, (void *)name, token);
}
...
int32 OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    /*
     * This is a no-op.
     *
     * Volatile volumes are just directories created in the temp dir,
     * and this will not remove the directories just in case something
     * went wrong.
     *
     * If the volume is started again, the directory will be re-used.
     */
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND (-17)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: int32 OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, OS_object_token_t *token)
explanation: I inspected all pointer usages in the provided code and related definitions. The following items do NOT require investigation for Rule 8.13: - The parameter devname in OS_rmfs is declared const char * (already const-qualified). - OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl accepts a const OS_object_token_t * (already const-qualified). - The token parameter in OS_ObjectIdGetByName is an output/transfer token and is written to by the called functions, so it must be non-const. - OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete (included above as suspicious to check if constness is appropriate) is observed to modify or use token in a way that requires a non-const pointer (it calls OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish and uses token->obj_id), so other uses of token in the code are appropriate as non-const. - The NULL passed to OS_NotifyEvent is an explicit null pointer constant and not relevant to const qualification. The only clear potential const-qualification issue is where a const char * (name) is cast to (void *) and passed to OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch; this discards constness and should be investigated. Other pointer parameters in the shown code are either already const or are legitimately non-const because they are modified.
